awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CICI: Secure and Resilient Architecture: S3D: A New SDN-Based Security Framework for the Science DMZ
awd_abstract_narration:
The Science DMZ (SDMZ) is a key foundational element in building state-of-the-art scientific research infrastructure. The SDMZ is a portion of the network, built at the campus or laboratory's edge, that is designed such that the equipment, configuration, and security policies are optimized for high-performance scientific applications rather than for general-purpose business systems or enterprise computing. SDMZs are increasingly being implemented by research agencies, campuses and national labs. In order to improve the throughput of scientific research data, NSF has funded many Science DMZ implementations on campuses by upgrading research network connectivity and encouraging installation of a SDMZ. However, the SDMZ has characteristics that separate it as a unique ecosystem which cannot simply adopt existing enterprise and cloud based network security technologies and policies. This project designs and prototypes an integrated Software Defined Network (SDN) security framework for managing data-intensive science applications utilizing the Science DMZ (SDMZ) model. It offers one of the first demonstrations of how fine-grained security controls can co-exist within a high performance data-intensive network. This project produces significant advancements in the trustworthiness and reliability of large-scale data-intensive scientific research infrastructures.

This project evaluates the current state of the SDMZ security architecture, then identifies the current shortcomings in its existing security services. The new proposed framework: 1) defines fine-grained network flow controls using dynamically deployable security services that are migratable and science-application aware; 2) defines a new class of network privilege management policies that can revoke or divert flows that violate SDMZ policies or that differ from user-defined, application-specific usage expectations; 3) establishes high-performance virtual circuits that enable data intensive applications to register and fast-path their authenticated flows across the SDMZ. Furthermore, this project introduces a unified security policy engine to dramatically simplify the control of the above three services. The policy engine offers a valuable and user-friendly abstraction to meet the domain-specific needs of the SDMZ.

por.por_cntn:
Our overall objective is the development of a security framework capable of meeting the range of unique functional requirements that arise in the Science DMZ (SDMZ) operating model, including the dynamic network policy management requirements involved in establishing distributed science experiments among computing assets hosted in multiple collaborating institutions.  The existing Science DMZ access rules that define its wide area network boundary policies do not support the expression of abusive flow behavior or the network privilege adjustments that should be made when such behaviors emerge within an ongoing flow. While it may be very common for a Science DMZ network server to establish flows with remote servers, it is difficult to express dynamic criteria under which such privileges should be revoked.

 

This project includes PIs from SRI International, Texas A&M University (TAMU) and Indiana University. We breifly list some of the key outcomes of this project below.

 

SRI's primary accomplishment this period was the introduction of CoordiNetz, which is a security extension to SDMZs that allows  project users (such as professors, scientists, researchers and students) an intuitive way to express fine-grained network, dataflow, and application policies. It provides application context to network nodes, enabling them to filter traffic or route it through DPI or a light-weight intrusion prevention system (LIPS). Contextual information built at the host DTNs is shared across the network-control and monitoring plane for fine-grained policy enforcement. CoordiNetZ integrates an intent-based policy management framework with context-based monitoring mechanisms, enabling users to express the expected experimental interactions and arbitrate conflicts with respect to project- and site-specific policies. Intent-based policies decouple what policies are to be enforced from how to enforce them. This abstraction is important, as science project policies must be flexibly specified by researchers rather than by administrators. We  developed a wide range of use-cases that demonstrate the benefits of our new security framework, and conducted a performance evaluation of our prototype CoordinetZ system.

 

The TAMU team has developed ForenGuard, which provides flow-level forensics and diagnosis functions in software-defined networks (SDN) for SDMZ. Unlike traditional forensics tools that only involve either network level or host level, ForenGuard monitors and records the runtime activities and their causal dependencies involving both the SDN control plane and data plane. Starting with a forwarding problem (e.g., disconnection) which could be caused by a security issue, ForenGuard can backtrack the previous activities in both the control and data plane through causal relationships and pinpoint the root cause of the problem. ForenGuard also provides a user-friendly interface that allows users to specify the detection point and diagnose complicated network problems. We implement a prototype system of ForenGuard on top of the Floodlight controller and use it to diagnose several real control plane attacks. We show that ForenGuard can quickly display causal relationships of activities and help to narrow down the range of suspicious activities that could be the root causes. Our performance evaluation shows that ForenGuard will add minor runtime overhead to the SDN control plane and can scale well in various network workloads.

 

The Indiana University team has developed the underlying technologies for generating and modifying flows between science DMZs predicated on both static and dynamic conditions on the network. We designed and implemented the network orchestration DSL Flange.  Flange is a terse declarative language designed to allow clients to enact changes on the network without directly interacting or referencing individual network resources.  Flange compiles requests from a custom, logic based, syntax into a variety of back-ends, depending on the requesting context. We have implemented several backend plugins for the Flange language. These include an eXtensible Session Protocol (XSP) plugin which allows Flange programs to request circuit tunnels established via XSP.  A Ryu Openflow controller plugin provides direct Openflow hooks to Flange, allowing it to exercise direct control over network switches orchestrated by a Ryu controller.

 

This project has trained several students in the design, implementation, evaluation, and presentation of networked systems.  This project has provided funding for several doctoral students to attend conferences and present their work.

 

The project provides a solid foundation and new approaches for developing more effective network security solutions, from the perspectives of both better understanding the nature of distributed cyber threats, and faster developing and evaluating more effective security defense mechanisms. For example, CoordinetZ, presented at ACSAC in December 2019, offered a unique reference prototype framework for and SDN-enhanced fine-grained dataflow-based security enforcement for global Science DMZ security coordination.
